bibl.title: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to Jefferson Randolph Kean, March 20, 1928

div1.p: Agramonte mentions how he enjoyed reading Kean's address for the opening of Belroi and requests a photograph of Reed's birthplace to hang in his office. He informs Kean of honors he received at a meeting in New Orleans. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to Jefferson Randolph Kean, March 20, 1928
div1.opener:
DR. ARISTIDES AGRAMONTE
CALLE K. ENTRE 15 Y 17
VEDADO, HABANA
March 20th, 1928
Col. Jefferson R. Kean,
Army Medical Museum.
Washington, D. C.
My dear Col. Kean:
div1.p:
The reprint of your address at the dedication of
Maj. Reed's birthplace, has just come to hand. I have read it
with the utmost delectation and enjoyed every word of it.

Let me thank you most sincerely for references which ap-
pear regarding myself.

Is it possible to obtain a copy of the photograph of the
house, that I would like to frame and hang in my office? Will
you try to get it for me?

Every word of your article is absolutely true and brings
to my mind fond memories of rather strenuous days.

I have just returned from New Orleans where I attended the
meeting of the American College of Physicians, at their invitat-
ion: Tulane University honored me with the degree of LL. D. and
the N. O. Association of Commerce presented me with a golden life-
membership card, in recognition of my work in the Army Board: we
also had banquets and receptions besides the scientific sessions,
which, by the way, were unusually excellent, according to reports.
I gave an address on the 5th and read a paper on the 9th, both of
which were very well received. I need not tell you how happy and
exalted I feel.

On reaching home I find an excellent picture p of General Wood
sent me from the Museum; will you be so good as to thank Maj. Col-
lender for the courtesy which I appreciate very highly.

With my best wishes and congratulations on your excellent
paper, I remain,
